conclusion: Analyze thermodynamic processes to determine net heat transfer.
p-V diagram shows two adiabatic (red curves) and two isochoric (vertical) processes.
Identify cycle processes: adiabatic (ac, cd) and isochoric (cb, da).
Adiabatic processes have no heat transfer (Q = 0).
Isochoric processes have constant volume; work done equals change in internal energy.
For isochoric processes cb and da, Q = ΔU (heat absorbed).
From a to b, Q = ΔU (heat absorbed).
From b to c, Q = ΔU (heat absorbed).
From c to d, Q = ΔU (heat absorbed).
From d to a, Q = ΔU (heat released).
Net heat absorbed (Q_net) is sum of heat absorbed minus heat released.
Net change in internal energy (ΔU) is positive, indicating more heat absorbed than released.
Amount of heat absorbed is greater than the amount of heat released.
